lines.text: I was peaches / I was cream / I was captain of the team!

I was so young at the time, I don't remember many of the things Daddy said about me. If he poured out his heart in this will, I'd kinda like to read it. "The reason I leave all my money to my son Junior is that, being of sound mind I can't leave my money to my wife, 'cause I ain't never forgiven her since the day she presented me with an idiot for a son." Well, I was the only child. "But this idiot is all I got in the world, which shows you what a lousy spot I'm in."
You're just like your old pa. He was the lyingest, crookedest, mangyest, rottenest, low down critter than never drew a silver breath.
Say, you really knew my daddy, didn't you? You, sir, have cast aspersions on my dear old daddy, the brave, low-down, mangy, crooked, drunken hero that won the West!
Put that gun away!
Let that be the thought for today.
I ought to blow out his yellow liver.
Blow out my liver, you'd mess up the onions.
Put it away!
Yeah, give me back my yellow liver, it matches my spine.
You know I don't believe in shooting.
Someday you'll be sorry you're so tenderhearted.
As I always say, tender heart never won tender liver.
[Kirk walks away]
I guess I was pretty stern with him.
Why, I'm so mean, I hate myself.
Where I hail from, we don't cotton to folks what cotton to other folks gals that don't cotton to folks that cotton to them. That's cotton talk, see?
I apologize, mister.
Oh, you do? Well then beat the whole kit 'n' caboodle of you. That's caboodle talk.

Say, it's gonna be real fun honeymooning in Niagara Falls. My daddy spent a whole week there on his honeymoon, laughing, loving, drinking champagne. He had so much fun, he kinda wished Mother had been with him.
When I was twelve, oh what a joy, Mom told me I was a boy!
Rock 'em, Sock 'em, Make 'em quit, Hit 'em where they know they're hit!
[Potter is talking to Mike in the saloon]
Now about that cellar...
Excuse me.
You're excused.
I'm talking to the lady.
Who do you think I'm talking to, a duck?
Let the man talk.
We don't need him.
What are you going to pay for that wagon with?
Ah, a preposition at the end of a sentence, and you split you infinitive. Pretty soon you'll be dangling a participle. Shame on you sir, the school marm will certainly hear about this.
